required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Early Protein Supplementation of Human Milk in Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Early Liquid Protein Supplementation of Human Milk in Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants

lead_sponsor.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

clinical_study.source: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock: We hypothesize that premature infants who receive their mothers' expressed breast milk supplemented with liquid protein early in their hospitalization will have a growth velocity in the first 28 days of life that is 20% greater than the growth velocity of premature infants that do not receive protein fortification.

primary_outcome.description: Growth velocity over the first 28 days of life - Daily weight measurements for the first 28 days of life

secondary_outcome.description: Extrauterine growth from birth until discharge from the NICU - Weekly weight measurements until discharge from the NICU
Extrauterine growth from birth until discharge from the NICU - Weekly length measurements until discharge from the NICU
Extrauterine growth from birth until discharge from the NICU - Weekly head circumference measurements until discharge from the NICU

arm_group.description: Study subjects will receive standard of care nutrition with the addition of a liquid protein supplement when the baby is able to tolerate an enteral feeding volume of 40mL/kg/day.
Study subjects will receive standard of care nutrition

intervention.description: The liquid protein supplement is already in use. The purpose of this study is to determine whether using the supplement earlier will lead to improved growth.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- inborn at Mount Sinai Medical Center
- gestational age between 26 0/7 weeks and 32 6/7 weeks gestation
- plan by family for their infant to receive human milk feeds
Exclusion Criteria:
- outborn infants
- gestational age < 26 0/7 weeks or > 33 0/7 weeks
- major congenital anomalies including cardiac disease, inborn errors of metabolism etc.
- sepsis and/or other serious clinical complication precluding initiation of enteral feeds
- plan by family for their infant to receive primarily preterm infant formula.

overall_official.affiliation: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

facility.name: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai
